document.docTitle: Tephritis ochroptera S. Korneyev, new species
document.masterDocTitle: Revision of species of the genus Tephritis Latreille 1804 (Diptera: Tephritidae) with entire apical spot

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of species of the genus Tephritis Latreille 1804 (Diptera: Tephritidae) with entire apical spot

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type material.
Holotype Ƥ: KYRGYZSTAN : 4148,7'N 7108,4'E h 1860 m , Chandalash ridge, Chon-Kurchak lakes, 28.7 km from Jangy-Bazar,
30 .VI. 1998
.

KYRGYZSTAN : 143, 2Ƥ, 4148,7'N 7108,4'E h 1860 m , Chandalash ridge, Chon-Kurchak lakes, 28.7 km from Jangy-Bazar,
30 .VI. 1998
(Korneyev & Kameneva); 1 Ƥ, 4141,1'N 7108,4'E h 1400-1700 m , Chatkal riv. valley, 15.3 km from Jangy-Bazar,
1 .VII. 1998
; 13, 1Ƥ, 4204,0'N 7135,8'E h 2210 m , Talas ridge, 76 km from Jangy-Bazar,

; 1 ?, 1 Ƥ, 4223,0'N 7135,8'E h 1500-2000 m , Kara-Bura valley, 43 km from Kok-Sai,

; 1 Ƥ, 4235,9'N 7547,4'E, h= 1450–1800 m , Boom Ravin,

,

6 .VII. 1982
(Isametdinov) (SIZK); UZBEKISTAN : 43, 1Ƥ, Chatkal Nature Reserve, Bashkyzylsai, S slope, on

,
10 .VI. 1981
(Beyko) (ZMUM).

Etymology. The specific epithet is a Latinised compound adjective derived of Greek ωχρός, pale, ochreous and πτερό, wing, feather meaning ochreous-winged; it is referring to its pale, yellowish or brownish grey wing pattern.

Diagnosis.
Tephritis ochroptera
can be readily differentiated from all known species of the genus
Tephritis
by the combination of the pale wing pattern with the mushroom-like grey spot at apex (instead of apical fork or 2 isolated spots) and largely confluent hyaline spots. In the group of species with entire apical spot or crossband, it is similar to
T. afrostriata
in its pale wing pattern, cell r 1 with two large spots and a small (additional) hyaline spot at its apex, and in abdominal tergites and oviscape at least partly yellow, clearly differing by the hyaline spots around crossveins r–m and dm-cu large and widely confluent; there is no grey crossband between pterostigma and crossvein dm-cu, typical for
T. afrostriata
.

Head. Entirely yellow, length: height: width ratio 1 : 1.1 : 1.4 . Frons as wide as high. Eye 1.4 times as high as long. First flagellomere of antenna 2.1 times as long as wide. Gena 0.5 times as high as length of first flagellomere. Setae as described for
T. admissa
.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 37–46.
Tephritis ochroptera
new species
37. Total view, holotype Ƥ. 38. Wing, paratype Ƥ 39. Epandrium and hypandrium, lateral right view. 40. Same, posterior view. 41. Glans of phallus, lateral. 42. Ejaculatory apodeme. 43. Male abdomen, dissected, dorsal view. 44. Aculeus, ventral view. 45. Apex of oviscape and eversible membrane, ventral view. 46. Spermathecae.

subSubSection.paragraph: Cell br hyaline in basal half, with pale browh with 3-4 hyline spots posterior to pterostigma; crossvein r–m with four isolated hyaline spots, sometimes fused into 2 bar-like spots. Cell r 4 + 5 at level of dm-cu with large hyaline spot, as wide as cell; medial portion of cell wide pale brown area including 1-5 small hyaline spots and separated by 8 -shaped hyaline spot and from dark apex of cell r 4 + 5 (sometimes connected to it by narrow bridge). Apical spot (apical crossband pale brown or ochreous grey, sometimes including 1-3 pale grey dots.

Cell m with 4 hyaline spots separated by narrow pale brown intervals or partly confluent. Cell dm hyaline at base, with 4-6 hyaline spots separated with narrow pale grey intervals. Cell cu and anal cell with narrow pale grey areas connected ino loose grid or separated. Anal lobe hyaline.

Abdomen. (
Fig. 44
) Tergites brown with yellow margins, grey microtrichose, otherwise as described for
T. afrostriata
.

Terminalia . Male. Epandrium (
Figs 39–40
) of oval shape common to other
Tephritis
species. Phallus without spines, glans (
Fig. 41
) moderately short, mostly membranous. Ejaculatory apodeme on
Fig. 42
. Female. Oviscape brownish-yellow, otherwise as described for
T. afrostriata
, as long as tergites 4-6 combined. Eversible membrane with two pairs of taeniae 0.35–0.4 times as long as membrane itself; dentate scales uniformly small, not enlarged medioventrally (
Fig. 45
). Aculeus moderately short, 5.6 times as long as wide, with evenly pointed apex (
Fig. 44
). Two papillose spermathecae 3.8-4.2 times as long as wide (
Fig. 46
).

Host plants: swept from
Cousinia refracta (Bornm.) Juz.
, which is probably a host plant.
